PSA - price filling logic V2 is almost ready. Prices can be retroactively updated in a 5 minute window after orders are placed based on websocket data and API data that was not initially available at the order fill. The logic always uses the price point that is closest to the order's processed time. The dashboard will now be able to display price debug info such as the data provider and the lag in miliseconds. @ptn・8 

Practically speaking, prices should be much more accurate due to the following 
* Price can be adjusted to a future price if the time delta is smaller than the assigned price's time. (A websocket price that comes in 1 ms after the order is better than a 2000 ms ping that came in before the order)

* Websocket data from TwelveData is now able to be fully utilized even if it has a ~2 minute lag. This allows us to have it as an equal-weight data provider in conjunction with Polygon data, minimizing gaps in price history.

For some insights into what is being developed with the new challenge period:

This is going to be an evolution of the grace period, designed as a preliminary way to filter miners incapable of consistently reaching some common milestones. Until your miner reaches the end of the challenge period, they will receive the same benefit as grace period miners. As of now, there are going to be five criteria needed to advance beyond this phase:

1. Number of returns
2. Total return
3. Sharpe ratio
4. Average amount of leverage
5. Total position duration

While we’re still determining the appropriate numbers for each of these categories, they will likely mirror the numbers used in a challenge like that of FTMO: https://ftmo.com/en/.

Once the miner reaches the end of the period, they will be subject to a day of judgment. If they do not meet the criteria, they will be eliminated. If they meet the criteria, they will enter the typical mining pool and receive incentive as usual.

I really don't see how its fair to retroactively change miners positions when the trades were executed using TwelveData's websocket (data had liveness and correctness) to Polygons 1 second rest api after the positions were already executed. This isn't a data corruption issue and the updated prices differences are very small(as to expect with different providers), but can have a large impact on miner performance. This is like trading on one exchange and having your closed positions and pnl changed using another exchanges data outside of major issue, it really doesn't make sense, there isn't some large magnitudinal data issue being dealt with here, but is just adds noise to miners positions who executed trades prior to the polygon update and adds randomness to the positions.
Why does retroactive price recalibration after websocket update need to be done instead of just using the new data provider going forward?
After the Twelve data websocket changes*. There were data issue before then

The TD websocket data used for OrderFillV1 could have several seconds of lag.

This recalibration has a significant impact on certain miners. To be fair, want to uniformly apply fixes to everyone.

Sending signals to validators can have over a minute worth of lag. None of these trading strategies can be high frequency to begin with so saving a second of two isn't really an issue, but swapping our executions with another data provider post trade does not sit rght.  The recalibration is not uniform as it skews to impact miners who traded on Twelve Data executions.
Its not so much a fix but a repricing.
I agree... I think the focus shouuld be on finding a solution to the lag getting to miners. Even if you don't have a HFT strategy, we should be able to execute trades quicker.

According to the current data, there are some timestamp discrepancies, but from what I've seen, these are just a few seconds. This is expected when placing orders during highly volatile times because of communication delays with the real exchanges. 

But the original prices differ greatly from the actual prices. So instead of having both incorrect timings and prices, recalibrating prices based on their timestamps ensures that the prices are accurate at those times. This seems more reasonable and fair.

If there is more than a several second lag between the miner's order and the validator receiving it, that is a bug. If it adversely affected your position please send me the logs and I can delete your position. Recent changes should have reduced lag significantly

@ptn・8  An update on the details of the challenge period, which will be rolled out on Monday, April 22, 2024 12:00:00 PM. There are four milestones which need to be met by your miner to progress into the main competition:

Minimum Sharpe Ratio - 1.1
Minimum Total Return - 2%
Minimum Number of Closed Positions - 10
Minimum Total Position Duration - 5 days

The challenge period will last for the first 30 days, or until your miner reaches all of the milestones and progresses to the main competition. If your miner still hasn't met the criteria to pass the challenge period by the end of 30 days, they will be eliminated. You only need to reach all of the thresholds once in order to advance. For example, if your return drops below 2% in the future after you pass the challenge period, you will not be sent back to the challenge period.

The total position duration will calculate the duration of each position as the difference between the close and the open times. If your miner has 5 positions open for one day before closing them, you will reach the minimum total position duration limit. For reference, the current top ten miners by return have an average total position duration of 380 hours or about 16 days.

@ptn・8 The challenge period has been rolled out - a final update on the challenge period, as some numbers were slightly modified. As before, the challenge period will last for a maximum of 30 days, after which your miner will be eliminated. To exit the challenge period, your miner must pass the following criteria:

2% Total Return
10 Closed Positions
50 Hours of total closed positions
20 Augmented MRAD

The augmented MRAD looks at the mean deltas on your returns relative to the median of your returns. An augmented MRAD of 5 means that your returns might typically swing 5x on average compared to your median return value. Please notify me if there is any unexpected behavior.

Additionally, given increased confidence in our miners’ strategies after passing the challenge period, we will now be making a couple of tweaks to the scoring function. Notably, you should expect to see omega removed and the time decay factor increased. The removal of omega is temporary, and will likely again become a major component when we roll our mid-trade risk profiling.

@ptn・8 I am now rolling out an update to the incentive distribution, which will impact miners who passed the challenge period. This update will prioritize returns and remove omega, changing the significance of each metric from:

Omega 40% -> 0%
Return 40% -> 80%
Sharpe 20% -> 20%

Additionally, this update will sharply cut the influence of historical trades, cutting the half life of a position from around 4 days to 16 hours. Due to this shorter cycle and removal of omega, we are also removing any evaluation of open positions for now. Let me know if any strange behavior arises. We additionally slightly increased the incentive towards the top, targeting 70 percent of the emissions to the top 30% of the miners. This is up from 60% to the top 40%.

Again, this is likely to change with the incorporation of mid trade risk profiling, which we are developing and hope to roll out soon. To help you in your long term planning, mid trade risk profiling will capture the movement of your asset and measure the volume of negative movements and positive movements. We will be tracking the level of risk you are exposing to the portfolio by holding onto positions as they are dropping, as well as any gains you are able to ride.
A bug was identified with the weights setting, and a patch was applied. Please let me know if you notice any other strange behavior.

Had a couple of questions on challenge period, posting here for visibility:

Q: Will challenge period trades count towards your score after challenge period?
A: Trades during the challenge period will count towards incentives after you pass the challenge period. After the challenge period, we only evaluate positions from the prior 30 days. However, there is pretty substantial decay on the potency of trades, so the trades that will likely make you competitive will continue to come after you are released from the challenge period. Note that there is still a consistency penalty, which provides a benefit to miners who have at least two weeks of regular trading activity.

Q: Do all criteria need to be met in order to pass the challenge period?
A: Yes. We rewind the history of positions, and if at any point a position is closed that pushes you out of the challenge period by meeting all criteria, then you are exited from the challenge phase and become a normal miner.

We will be transitioning to a new scoring system this week, based on a new mid trade risk profiling system. To summarize for those who aren’t up to date, a quick recap: the new system will track value change for each position based on real time changes to the price of the asset. Risk will be defined as any negative value change that occurs while the miner is holding onto the asset. Given that the price of assets fluctuates so quickly and has some level of noise, it is virtually impossible for an investment strategy to have zero risk. This is normal. With this update, open positions will be evaluated constantly based on the most recent change in value that they provide along with closed positions.

We plan to use two scoring metrics long term to evaluate miners based on their mid trade scores: Omega and Sortino. Omega will evaluate the magnitude of the positive asset changes over the magnitude of negative asset changes. Any score above 1 will indicate that the miner experienced a net gain through the course of their position. A higher omega value will result from:

1. Higher magnitude positive value change
2. Pure positive value change

Sortino measures the pure volume of losses, and will be divided by the total time duration of investments. That is, how much loss is the miner likely exposing per unit of time. A lower sortino value indicates a more effective risk mitigation strategy. This will result from:

1. Less leverage utilization
2. Pure positive value change

@ptn・8 Our current top miners seem to have quite effective trading strategies, but high leverage use will inflate sortino values as more risk is potentially introduced into the portfolio. Given the high level of historical decay we currently have, current top performing miners should be able to transition quickly to the introduction of sortino by reducing their leverage usage. I’m attaching photos as well to visualize the change. There are two cartoon photos which simplify the concepts, and a visualization against real historical data for Tarvis. In the real historical photo, Omega will be calculated as the amount of green in the first photo over the amount of red. The second plot shows the difference between the gains and losses while Tarvis was holding a position, a higher level of green indicates that Tarvis has a positive Omega value. The sortino ratio will look at the entire volume of red, and normalize over the sum of time that positions were open.

Hi @kabar , thanks for the questions. The delta period is one second on average between updates, and we're going to implement a 10 second cooldown between orders . If the ratio of growth is higher than the ratio of losses, your miner will score better. So in this example you sent, miner B has no losses, so the score will be huge, miner A has only small losses, likely still a large omega between the differences, and miner C would have a larger loss delta sum, as there are more losses - correct. If the gain of miner C is substantially higher though, this may offset some of the loss delta for the omega calculation. Your second photo is also correct.

Unlike the position based system we were using before, risk profiling will not "cancel" losses when a position is closed. Please note we will be using another metric called sortino, which will only look at the time averaged sum of loss deltas (how much risk are you taking per unit of time). Both example C and example D would score poorly in sortino compared to the other two. We are also changing the relationship between these scoring functions to be multiplicative instead of additive for the final score, such that top miners will need to score well for both Omega and Sortino- even if you score no loss, capturing no positive gains will likely disqualify you from being competitive.  Finally, historical decay still plays a role - this time you can think of it like each delta is receiving a time decay, instead of each closed position.

We are also requiring a minimum total time engagement with the platform of 50 hours (the same as the challenge period), which will be the sum of all position durations which were open for the miner in the past 30 days, now including open positions.

**Scoring Metrics**
There are three metrics which will be used initially for scoring our miners: Returns, Omega and duration normalized Sortino. Returns will be computed as before, as the Omega is calculated as the ratio of gains to losses. Duration normalized Sortino will look at the volume of losses accrued by the miner and divide by the total duration of open positions. To encourage our miners to generalize well, we are augmenting the scoring function to multiply their scores from each scoring function instead of adding them.

We will start with a 50/100/100 split between Returns, Omega and Sortino, which may be adjusted slightly as we try to evaluate the appropriate level of risk which will make our traders into the most attractive product. This is a bit different from the additive system we used before. Your score in returns now has the capacity to reduce your overall score by 50%, Omega now has the capacity to reduce by 100%, and so on. Ranking poorly in either Omega or Sortino will likely disqualify you from being competitive long term.

**Challenge period**
Upon rollout, the challenge period will remain the same and be position based. This will be updated soon to also use the same mid trade risk profiling system.

Switching positions is a great idea, we'll look into it 🤝 

Omega CPS and Sortino CPS have some level of relationship- Sortino is looking at the normalized volume of losses that the miner experiences. Taking on positions with higher leverage over longer periods of times will likely introduce a higher volume of losses for the miner, increasing the sortino (bad). Omega is looking at the ratio of gains to losses. If your miner is capable at detecting the correct general market movement, then the omega will be high, and higher leverage will allow you to further increase your omega if leverage is utilized well. In general, Omega can be thought of as an efficiency metric - how well are you able to capture gains relative to your losses. Longer positions with smaller gains will increase the volume of gains and losses, such that the difference between them is less impressive. Smaller positions with substantial gains will score much better. So both timing of the position and utilization of proper leverage will help you score well. Timing will also likely help with your Sortino, although high leverage will always introduce a risk that you might track larger losses.

Ok, thanks for explaining. And do I understand right that for the closed position those all metrics (sortino, omega_cps, return) are multiplied to generate "position scoring" that's impact on final miner weight decreases over time (so that way f.ex. sortino of particular position is also less and less important for miner's performance as position gets older) ?

Actually both closed and open positions will be used for scoring now, any recorded deltas from the positions over the past 30 days. Historical decay is currently designed to decay all gains and losses at the same rate, and you're correct that we're now using multiplication instead of addition for each of the scores. There are three terms which are decayed at the same rate - gains, losses, and open_ms. Omega is the ratio of gains over losses, so your omega value will actually stay the same if you don't open any new positions. Sortino is loss over open_ms, so it will also stay the same with historical decay. However returns are the sum of log gains and log losses, and thus will reduce to zero with historical decay.

Your final score will be the product of scores for each of the three categories. Ranking at the bottom of Omega or Sortino will drop your total score to 0. Ranking at the bottom of Returns will drop your score by 50%.

I understand we added a bit of complexity with the most recent update, there are a few moving parts here which makes the project particularly unique and scoring a challenge. First is that we want to reward miners immediately based on their contributions, which is unique to prop firms. With a pure returns based strategy, this was resulting in an imbalance of incentive, where miners would yolo trade and frequently hit the drawdown limit. If someone was copy trading this miner, they would be left with a 10% account loss at the moment of elimination. The incorporation of more advanced analytics for risk management was necessary as we avoid this scenario while providing real time benefit. @kabar , the miner you highlighted: 5C8Wegdus2cAcwSNU47MdiLXwZdewFkSv93xUWQP3wn32QJV has pretty aggressive use of leverage, regularly using 5x leverage and going to 50-75x. @ptn・8 Thank you everyone for your feedback with the new risk adjusted incentive mechanism! You brought some great topics to the table, and I want to share an update on the upcoming development horizon, based on your feedback and some of our ongoing discussions.

We changed the scoring incentive distribution to more heavily weigh returns. This is now active. This has a couple of benefits, including easier translation of trades for copy trading and greater stability among the top miners. The new scoring distribution will be:

Returns CPS: 0.5 -> 0.90
Omega CPS: 1.0 -> 0.75
Sortino CPS: 1.0 -> 0.60

Note: 0.9 = 1 - (1-0.75) * (1-0.6), so we're now using a 50/50 split between returns and risk metrics. This is likely that we will continue to tweak the system as we get more feedback from the community and examine how people are using the system, although our goal is to reduce the amount of changes over time.

We are also moving to use a different historical decay on the risk metrics, such that the omega and sortino scores are computed with more significance from historical transactions. The objective here is to allow traders who have historically demonstrated responsible trades to take more risk if need on a position, and provide benefit for consistent performers.

Finally, we will look to incorporate a baseline return using U.S. treasury bills. This will likely be a static parameter which will increase the loss by a baseline amount each checkpoint period. The objective of this will be to penalize traders who are not active, and enable us to reduce or remove existing time criteria.

and if anything, these changes very much assist end clients. Prioritizing risk metrics but _not_ returns makes the following scenario a possibility:

a miner who has performed very well with risk metrics but has not provided much in terms of returns has been the top miner for the past 30 days, receiving a lot of incentive, yet never surpassed 5% returns. Say they had 3.5% returns. Their miner then gets eliminated due to drawdown by misstepping on a position. All clients are now at a 1.5% loss even though the miner was being prioritized as the top miner. 

by not prioritizing returns enough, this scenario can certainly happen. In order to avoid this scenario, we need to increase prioritization of returns. 

separately:

The objective here is to allow traders who have historically demonstrated responsible trades to take more risk if need on a position, and provide benefit for consistent performers.

with this change, we'll be able to apply pressure to provide returns (with a faster decay on returns) while also providing more upside in terms of incentive for those who have a track record of success. This balance is required to ensure risk management is maintained.

these changes provide the infrastructure for us to maintain a balance of risk management & returns, making both a priority.

@ptn・8  - R2.5.3 (MERGED)
We are now rolling out a new historical augmentation, which decays the risk adjusted metrics at a slower rate compared to the returns. The potency of returns (defined as gains - losses from each checkpoint) decays by 50% in just 18 hours, the same rate as before. However, the potency of the values used for calculating the risk adjusted metrics now decay to 50% in around 22 days. This should allow miners who have historically demonstrated good risk management to take a bit more risk if needed in capturing a high return. It should also help to stabilize the values for the risk metrics and avoid sharp fluctuations. The weights used in calculating the score remain the same.

@ptn・8 Two major updates will come soon, although they haven't been released yet: **Max Drawdown** and **Challenge Period**

__Max Drawdown:__
We will be simplifying the drawdown rules by removing the 5% daily limit and reducing the 10% instantaneous to only 5% instantaneous drawdown. This means that if your portfolio value ever drops by 5% from its peak, you will be eliminated. This is meant as a protection for copy traders using the outputs of PTN, to protect them from a more severe 10% loss in the case of a significant market shift. This isn’t going to be retroactive, and will only impact future transactions.

__Challenge Period:__
There will be changes to the challenge period soon, as we transition it to the new checkpoint based risk scoring system. As a reminder, all miners currently on the system will be transitioned to the new system without having to pass the challenge period again.

New Challenge Period Criteria:
Time Averaged Sortino Minimum: **-1.5E-8**
Omega Minimum: **1.0015**
Return Minimum: **3.5%**

These were based on the current median values for each statistic, with the exception of the sortino, which is set to the 60th percentile. Note, the minimum time duration criteria for the challenge period has been eliminated.

We are increasing the duration of the challenge period from 30 days to 45 days to better accommodate lower drawdown limits. You will now have 45 days to reach these minimum criteria for your miners. If beyond 45 days you have still not reached the minimums your miner will be eliminated. As the metrics have changed slightly, all challenge period times will be reset to the time of update. You will have 45 days from the moment the system is released to pass the challenge phase, your existing positions will count towards meeting these new criteria.

I'm not sure if it would be theoretically possible to achieve new challenge metrics with 1 transaction, but if it would, I suggest to leave current 10 transaction limit to avoid situations when someone lucky just tricks the metrics.

To ensure sustained performance from our miners during challenge period, there is a slight modification to the updated challenge period rules.

__Challenge Period:__
As a reminder, all miners currently on the system will be transitioned to the new system without having to pass the challenge period again.

New Challenge Period Criteria:
Time Averaged Sortino Minimum: -1.5E-8
Omega Minimum: 1.0015
Return Minimum: 3.25%
Volume Minimum Checkpoints: 12 (3 days)

These were based on the current median values for each statistic, with the exception of the sortino, which is set to the 60th percentile. Note, the minimum time duration criteria for the challenge period has been eliminated in favor of a volume based criteria, which should have a similar effect.

The volume minimum checkpoints will be computed as the sum of gains and the absolute value sum of losses. This is set to be around the 25th percentile of all checkpoints, a value of 0.1. This means that a checkpoint with gains of 0.05 and losses of -0.05 would qualify with an absolute sum of 0.1, as would a checkpoint with a gain of 0.1 and a loss of 0.0. For reference, around 75% of the checkpoints from Tarvis hit this threshold.

The challenge period will remain at 30 days, apologies for the change of plans- the required return is reduced to 3.25% from 3.50% in consideration of this reduced time.

messages.content: @ptn・8 This week we'll be rolling out a small change which will introduce a baseline return for all miners, tied to the annual returns of American Treasury Bills (~5%). This will be introduced as a small, constant loss to each checkpoint adjusted for time. The logic for this change is that if a miner chooses not to invest over a period, they would have missed an opportunity to profit with a constant return. This change is likely to have a more substantial impact on traders with low trading volume, and a negligible impact on traders with higher volume. This will impact both the challenge period and the main competition, challenge period metrics will be updated accordingly to meet the same percentiles of quality.

```
The logic for this change is that if a miner chooses not to invest over a period, they would have missed an opportunity to profit with a constant return.
```
The opportunity cost is from taking the trade not from sitting in cash, PTN is limited so you can't get risk-free* yield on your cash that you otherwise could. Think of it like this: would a partner rather have their capital tied up for 1 month to get a 2% return or 1 week? Sounds like you almost have it backwards, probably missing something so let me know.
Would this loss also apply to the DD requirements?  Will it be easy to distinguish between normal returns?  I'm also concerned this change would bring a lot of confusion

Apologies, a bit too much terminology. This baseline will essentially simulate investment into treasury bills using an equivalent 100% portfolio utilization (1x leverage) risk free investment. It will spread the 5% annual return over every millisecond. Each month for example will receive a baseline loss of ~0.4% regardless of trading activity. If your Omega is less than 1 in a month, it indicates that you could not beat the risk free rate over that month.

Volume is a reference to the absolute sum of gains and losses - essentially the amount of activity overseen by the trader's positions. If your gains and losses are both quite small, the impact of a constant loss will have a more substantial impact on your metrics.

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treynor_ratio
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jensen%27s_alpha

https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1162384774170677318/1227747285228851270  ... @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ] will it still be relevant?

We use a system of checkpoints to reduce the memory footprint of saving all gains and loss activity from every second on each asset. Each checkpoint stores about 6 hours of information, and accum_ms indicates the current length of time that's been tracked in a single checkpoint. Thus cp_accum_ms * baseline_gain_rate will give the baseline normalized loss over the number of milliseconds that the checkpoint has been open

This will likely drop the omega from 0.75 to 0.3, and sortino from 0.6 to 0.2. Currently the risk metrics have the ability to drop your score by 90% = 1 - ((1-0.75)*(1-0.6)). There are two directions we need to move right now, which almost live on opposite sides of the same coin. First, we need to encourage more frequent and consistent trading behavior, which en emphasis on returns should do. Next, we need to reduce incentive to make an over leveraged trade and sit on it for too long. This update will likely also introduce a change to the consistency penalty- the current consideration is this:

If max trading volume on a single checkpoint is substantially greater than the median trading volume over all checkpoints, there will be a substantial penalty to the miner's score. This would be a modification to the current system, which only checks for minimum volume in a checkpoint. Main Notes for Consistency Release @Terps @Aaron | Timeless @Gugua @sirouk | TuDudes [τ, ⛏] @ZHawk 

More weight will be provided to returns and less to omega / sortino
Consistency penalty is significantly overhauled
Slightly more incentive will go to the top 40%, but spread among these top miners
Returns have a slightly higher decay rate

The consistency change will likely have the biggest impact in addition to the changes in the scoring incentive, so I will highlight the primary changes here.

To clarify, margins are defined as gains - losses over a checkpoint period.

To generate a more consistent product, usable by validators, we want to provide an incentive for miners to have returns behavior in line with past transactions. This idea is similar to that of the one utilized by FTMO: https://ftmo.com/en/consistency-is-very-important-for-success-in-trading/. The consistency of your miner will be determined by looking at the time normalized margins on each checkpoint. We look at the most extreme margins for the miner, and compare it to the typical checkpoint behavior. FTMO uses the extreme margin divided by the sum of margins. This tells FTMO what percentage of the margins were captured by a single position. We choose to use the extreme margin divided by the median. The median allows us to avoid the influence of these extreme values in determining the abnormality of the checkpoint period.

This abnormality score is then run through a sigmoid to determine the penalty of the miner. The system is currently designed to only impact the largest discrepancies - a margin of 3x the standard in one period for example yields a miner less than 1% consistency penalty.

Miners who have no trading activity over half of the trading activity are seen as being too inconsistent to reasonably consider including in a real trading strategy, and will have a severe consistency penalty.

This system provides a few benefits:
1. An extreme trade will immediately impact the miner’s consistency penalty if they yield an abnormally large margin compared to their past activity, dropping their benefit to 0 immediately.
2. A miner is able to ramp into a new strategy by slowly increasing or decreasing the volume of their margins, which will augment their median value without incurring substantial consistency penalty.
3. We are able to reduce the minimum time requirements for trading

In the new checkpoint logic, we have also introduced a ramp on period, similar to that of the old checkpoint system. This new system will exponentially ramp the miner’s consistency score until they reach three weeks, assuming that they have a reasonable consistency score. This is a requirement due to the fact that it simply takes a longer period of time to understand the miner’s behavior before a validator might choose to utilize the miner’s information in real trades.

We will likely continue augmenting features of this consistency penalty, to better account for individual position usage of high leverage and portfolio max drawdown, so this will be part one.

Details on the implementation may be found in the open PR: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/pull/191

e.g. take a strategy that gets big profits only at specific times (12:00 ~ 15:00 every day, or when something opening). that strategy would get huge penalties if it doesn't do as well at other times. Hi @tmt [τ, τ], thanks for your feedback. I understand there are a number of things to consider for miners, and we are looking to make the system simpler. For example, this new consistency change will allow for reduced time durations / volumes, and the reduced 5% MDD has allowed us to focus more heavily on returns while retaining some level of stability. We are also looking at replacing Sortino with something directly related to MDD, as sortino seems to be one of the main sources of confusion for miners - Omega is much more closely related to pure returns. We are additionally increasing the significance of returns as the primary scoring function, which should simplify things a bit for miners.

That being said, we need to curate a signal which is usable as a sellable product. It’s possible a miner with higher returns could score lower than a highly consistent miner, this is because we need to prioritize the expectation of future returns over past returns. A miner who has one or two great trading periods is simply too inconsistent, and we can’t build a trading strategy against them. For example, here are some miners who are currently doing well, based on a small number of highly successful trades:

5Exax1W9RiNbARDejrthf4SK1FQ2u9DPUhCq9jm58gUysTy4
5DaHdgTLPrGCdiNMosKq9GEpDmA6pPaMvNopXtnG28AtYghm
5EF393sRCV3Q6SFNTpKQed8m3QDGRgfDvke8sUoH3kbLqGZS

Baking in a consistency measure will give anyone selling our signals a higher level of confidence that our miners will have similar behaviors moving forward. We are starting with a reasonably low bar for the threshold of consistency as we run a preliminary pruning of these extreme miners - your miner will only start to receive penalties if your max margins on a period are 90x larger than your typical behavior or you have no activity on more than half of all periods. You are always welcome to increase your median with higher leverage trades and reduce your penalty by becoming more consistent.

We are very concentrated on getting as many paying clients/partners access to the signals as possible, but are working on a few things first to get there. 

1. Request Network Launch to Mainnet - end of May/early June (delay due to new feature requests)

This requires first getting the request network up and running with validators. We are going through testing on staging, and also adding new features that certain validators have requested, such as the ability to have clients pay via Stripe rather than web3. 

With the request network any validator will be able to register and spin up services to sell to consumers. For PTN, we've already setup pre-created endpoints that validators will be able to spin up and sell. We also have partners already leveraging these endpoints (free of charge via RT21) so the transition to using the endpoints via the request network should be straight forward for them. They'll simply need to pay and point their systems to the new endpoint. 

2. Create Differentiating Access Between Validators - end of May

While validators can choose what services they provide and how they provide those services, we want to differentiate which validators get access to what data from the network. Essentially, the idea of network bandwidth. This means that bigger validators will have access to more data, while smaller ones have access to less. This is something that we're working to finalize. 

3. Taoshi Trading System (TTS) - end of May

We are delivering an OSS trading system which will allow any client to take the signals from PTN, and plug into a variety of exchanges and brokers. This system is specifically built to handle millions in funds, and can scale to the needs of any client/partner. It integrates with Binance, dYdX, WOO X, and MetaTrader5. This should streamline the process for new partners to come join and sell services to customer bases, and enable existing partners to expand their products. Timeless for example, will be using this to enable their automated trading for their client base. 


Taoshi will also be using TTS for the purposes of building a product to take on customers at scale to leverage the output of PTN. This has been in the works. We'll have a more formal announcement on this soon.
we're also simultaneously working to expand our list of partners, and we'll have some announcements on some new rather big partners who'll be paying for access to the data

@ptn・8 The most recent scoring update has been rolled out, with a number of tweaks. The most notable changes are:
1. Increase in the priority of returns as a primary driver in the system

While the details can be found in the recently merged PR and in communication above, the consistency penalty will look at the maximum action taken in a single checkpoint period and compare this to median behavior of the miner. If there is a substantial discrepancy, the miner is deemed inconsistent and they will receive a penalty. We require a level of engagement with the system to be comfortable evaluating the consistency of the miner, and have an 18 day ramp in period through which the miner will exponentially accrue consistency points. We will likely look to move towards a system that prioritizes miners who have almost no drawdown, as they are less likely to blow their accounts and take losses on open positions for validators purchasing their signals. @ptn・8 By popular demand, we have removed Sortino from the scoring mechanism. Sortino was meant to serve as an instrument of risk mitigation, to reduce the probability of high drawdown events. For this role it will be missed by all those who used it well 🪦 . In its place, we are going to be directly using the current drawdown of miners, penalizing miners who have a max drawdown above 2.5% with an exponential penalty applied to a max drawdown of 5% and beyond. All of this information for drawdown, and much more regarding statistics for miners, will be available on the dashboard soon.

This change also brings about a **removal of eliminations** due to drawdown limits, which has been disabled since last night.

This new system will now use the instantaneous drawdown for each miner, based on the instantaneous max value and the instantaneous min value - otherwise the logic remains the same. This change was made to live in harmony with the scoring system, which evaluates the quality of miner predictions in real time.

The penalty will examine the max drawdown values from the last two weeks, and use the largest drawdown value to determine your penalty. A couple of hypothetical examples to help you understand how the process works:

- Miner A takes a 10x leverage position on bitcoin. Bitcoin rises 1%, and falls 1%. Miner A closes the position. Miner A will have a 10% mdd for the next two weeks, after which the penalty will be cleared assuming no other trades take place.
- Miner B takes a 10x leverage position on bitcoin. Bitcoin falls 1%. Miner B closes the position. Miner B will also now have 10% mdd for two weeks, but assuming no other trades will still be in 10% mdd relative to starting position two weeks prior. They will continue to have a penalty until the prior value is purged from the checkpoints after 30 days.

The penalty structure is as follows:

MDD - Penalty
0% - 0%
1% - 0%
2% - 0%
3% - 5%
4% - 25%
>5% - 100%

One point of further clarification to be safe - in our old system the max portfolio value was defined against closed positions. This is no longer the case, as we are constantly evaluating the miners' open positions and establishing the max portfolio value based on the highest instantaneous value achieved. The discrepancy between the maximum value and the current instantaneous portfolio value defines the current drawdown, including open positions. If there is any confusion with this, please feel free to ask.

A couple of things I should clarify to clear the air a bit - when this was rolled out we were using risk adjusted metrics for scoring with more weight. Decay with the same weight on both the returns and the losses would enable a situation in which the risk adjusted metrics might have remained the same, allowing a miner to sit on a trade for a long period of time. As we transitioned to more returns, this is no longer necessary, and now we are pushing a change to update the scoring function for equal decay for the losses and the gains, this is coming soon.

Our penalties are incremental - you can improve your consistency penalty with more similar trades, and if you don't improve your drawdown relative to your max portfolio value then you will continue to receive a penalty. We are also using this update to introduce another metric for the scoring function - long term returns. This will operate exactly the same as the short decay returns, but over a longer time horizon. Top miners with this new incentive will need to score well both historically in returns and recently. This should further provide incentive for miners to continue trading during penalty periods, so as to stay competitive when their penalties are removed.

Stay tuned, changes coming soon @Terps

@ptn・8 
We just rolled out R2.7.4, with a number of incremental changes:
* **We have introduced a new feature to the scoring mechanism**, which looks at the returns over the last three weeks. This will enable a new layer to view the quality of miners, by incentivizing gains over longer periods such that top miners are likely bringing 3-5% returns per month. We still want to encourage movement on the top, so a bottom tier score in this metric will only reduce the overall score by 50% instead of 95% like with the short term returns.
* Historical decay: with the shift to a returns based function, **we will now remove any variable decay between losses and gains**. This should make for a more interpretable output on the augmented scores and remove any potential biases against high volume traders.
* Percentile based scoring function: We would prior look at the ranking of each scoring metric and convert this ranking to a penalty for the miner. For example, if we have three miners: 0.95, 0.93, 0.4 - the 1st place score might be converted to 1.0, second place converted to 0.7, 3rd place would be 0.4, etc. Now, **we will look at the percentile of each score relative to other miners for individual scoring functions**, such that with our example miners the top two will both be much closer to 1. This will enable a higher resolution of competition at the top, such that even small improvements might be able to propel you to the next spot.
* **Drawdown penalty has been increased**. We are looking to prioritize miners who bring in over 5% per month while only hitting ~1% MDD, similar benchmarks to FTMO. To do this, we are setting the penalty for MDD to be 1.5% instead of 2.5%, and increasing the steepness of the penalty.
* Consistency penalty tweak. We are slightly increasing the penalty for consistency, part of the broader plan to slowly increase consistency penalty to more reasonable figures after a preliminary pruning of extremely inconsistent miners.

I understand the frustration, but as the MDD uses the maximum value seen the probability that a miner will be competitive with a 5% MDD on their record is essentially impossible due to the MDD penalty. We must keep pushing towards a system capable of consistent and reliable returns, both in rewarding miners and identifying talent via challenge period.

To clarify, the current structure of the challenge period is as follows:
  - Minimum 2.5% Total Return
  - Minimum 1.0015 Omega
  - Maximum 2% Instantaneous MDD
  - Minimum 12 Volume Checkpoints

The volume minimum checkpoint is defined as a checkpoint which meets a certain threshold of raw gains and losses. The threshold value for inclusion of the checkpoint as valid is 0.1. This means that a checkpoint with a gain of 0.05 and a loss of -0.05 would have an absolute sum of 0.1 and qualify. We are requiring 12 of these valid checkpoints to have been observed in order for the miner to pass the checkpoint qualifications.

Weights are based on a product sum- short term returns have the largest capacity to reduce your overall score. If you are the 0th percentile in terms of recent returns, your overall score will drop by 95%. If you are the 0th in long term returns, your score will drop by 50%, and if you are 0th in Omega your score will drop by 20%.

Recent returns will likely determine your place within the top 5, but you will likely need strong long term returns in order to be among the top miners. We hope that a stronger preference towards recent returns will enable a good amount of shuffling amongst the top miners as they capture gains.

I’d like to preface this by saying the incentive mechanism should be close to solidified at this point. We’re not looking to make anymore major adjustments. We believe the current ruleset incentivizes the right behavior by miners, which took many iterations, review, and resources to achieve (as many of you know).

The ideal miner provides the following — 5% return monthly with <1.5% mid-trade drawdown.

The goal of the network is to create a consistent print by the top miners with low drawdown. Low drawdown was determined to be <1.5% mid-trade drawdown based on inspecting a variety of cases, especially considering mid-trade drawdown is max positional return to local low. Meaning, if a miner has a 10% return on a trade and then drops to 8.5% they would be at the cusp of penalty with a 1.5% mid-trade drawdown. 

By doing so, we can gracefully allow clients to scale in and out of positions based on the shift in incentive / score of each miner with the penalty.

As long as a miner is performing with the low risk and high returns, they shouldn’t be penalized. However, if they deviate into higher drawdown territory (>1.5% mid-trade) they should be penalized as they’re showing they may have lost control of the trade’s downside risk from what would be considered normal. As the penalty sets in, the miners incentive and rank would drop, clients would be able to reduce the size of the position of their trades, and reduce risk from that miner.

Definitely thanks for the feedback @Terps, always appreciated. For some background with the 1.5% choice - there's some potential random noise from the high resolution of pricing data we collect, which may at times cause price fluctuations. This and the inherent necessity of taking some level of drawdown for any trading strategy is what motivated the shielding at 1.5%, under which we believe a trader is operating responsibly.

To give some perspective on the conversation of expected value, let's live in the scenario where we have a 2% gain and 2% dd miner with a 1% gain and 1% dd miner. This plot shows the margins captured for a checkpoint vs the max drawdown taken over the prior 24 hour period - if miners were generally able to capture higher margins with higher drawdown, we should see a linear trend here up and to the left, which is not the case. Given the relative lack of relationship between drawdown and returns, the choice of penalty for mdd won't be used as an equivalency of expected value but largely determined by the relative risk assumed by the partners in taking on the trades for a miner^

This is also complicated by the fact that we currently don't impose leverage restrictions on trading behavior. Without leverage restrictions, partners are more exposed to the scenario where multiple miners make a high leverage trade on the same asset in a given moment, over utilizing their capacity. Measuring instantaneous drawdown is one of our primary mechanisms for regulating responsible leverage use, which is why the penalty will likely continue to have some form of exponential dropoff.

Objectives as we transition drawdown over the 30 day period:
1. Slight relaxation on penalty intensity as more period will be included, thus increasing the probability of high drawdown events
2. Fully continuous penalty towards zero drawdown
3. Continued assessment of risk assumption on validators in designing the decay curve for mdd

When designing penalty intensity / curve, the penalty should be a reflection of how to discount the signal before serving to partners. When framed like this I think its illuminating. Those objectives all sound great for the sn.

Thanks for this information @Terps , you’ve got a lot of great ideas and have been awesome for the community. Let’s dig into this a bit - let’s say we’ve got a person with an identical strategy, but multiple miners using different leverages on the same strategy.

Low Leverage: 1% MDD -> 1% returns
Typical Behavior: 2% MDD -> 2% returns
High Leverage: 3% MDD -> 3% returns
Highest Leverage: 4% MDD -> 4% returns

These are the multipliers proposed in your linear system:
1% DD -> 0.8
2% DD -> 0.6
3% DD -> 0.4
4%DD -> 0.2
5%DD -> 0

Let’s translate this to our identical miners:
Low Leverage: 1% MDD -> 0.8 returns
Typical Behavior: 2% MDD -> 1.2 returns
High Leverage: 3% MDD -> 1.2 returns
Highest Leveage: 4% MDD -> 0.8 returns

If we want to normalize for expected value of the returns under the assumption that leverage is directly proportional to the leverage usage and MDD, we should shoot for something like 1/MDD as the penalty:

1% DD -> 1.0 -> 1 returns
2% DD -> 0.5 -> 1 returns
3% DD -> 0.33 -> 1 returns
4%DD -> 0.25 -> 1 returns
5%DD -> 0.2 -> 1 returns

This will likely serve as our core penalty, but two issues pop up - if your miner gets unlucky and extends the MDD, you will now have the incentive to scale your leverage to operate under this new MDD limit - this might creep your leverage usage up over time. To mitigate this, we will introduce an additional augmentation to this, which exponentially increases the penalty towards 5% MDD. The other issue is that extremely small leverage positions would actually get a boost, although their translation to a real copy trading system is not as intuitive as you may be multiplying by huge numbers to translate them into reasonable sized trades. A cliff between 0 and 1 would help mitigate this abnormality

We still have some other policies in place @Aaron | Timeless - you'll need to score well with the consistency penalty (which means that a single large trading period with no prior history will be detrimental), limited drawdown, and a long history of gains. We don't want to run into a situation where there isn't a level of competition at the top, and feel that short term returns when paired with these long term penalties makes for a competitive ecosystem amongst top traders. If there's strange behavior or unskilled traders on the top feel free to point them out and we can look into their statistics

As a heads up, we will be changing the MDD penalty soon and tweaking the consistency penalty. Thank you for your feedback everyone, particularly @Terps and @tmt [τ, τ] ! The consistency penalty update is fairly straightforward, just a slight improvement on how we measure consistency to help avoid outlier events. The MDD penalty will introduce a few more changes:

The mdd penalty will normalize the returns by multiplying your returns by 1 / MDD. This is true even for small drawdown, which will actually receive a bonus from this modification. The following miners will have an equivalent return for scoring purposes:

Miner 0: MDD 0.25% - Return 0.5%
Miner 1: MDD 0.5% - Return 1%
Miner 2: MDD 1% - Return 2%
Miner 3: MDD 1.5% - Return 3%

To discourage miners from trading with incredibly small leverage, we are capping the benefit to low MDD miners at an equivalent value of 0.25% MDD. Additionally, to help prevent runaway leverage usage over time, we are adding a linear penalty in addition to the leverage normalization, and miners beyond 5% MDD will have a full penalty setting their returns to 0. Key takeaway - the zone with no effective penalties will be between 0.25% MDD and 1.5% MDD. If you are within this region, then your penalty will simply work as a balance for the expected value of returns. Additionally, the MDD period will now extend for 30 days, instead of two weeks, to balance against the long term returns used for scoring.

@ptn・8 We really appreciate your feedback, and want to give you a better opportunity to voice your concerns prior to any substantial changes. We’re going to do our best to follow these steps before rolling out new changes, as well as slowing down the general rate of changes on the network:

1. Announcement that we are working on a new feature and will have a proposal out by a certain date
2. Provide the proposal to you for a round of feedback
3. Take feedback and update the proposal
4. Second round of feedback if needed
5. Timeline of release for the changes based on the proposal
6. Release of the proposed solution on said date

3. our incentive mechanism aligns with currently used client expectations, meaning our incentive is a weighted average for portfolio allocation. Its plug & play for them as incentive sums to 1 so we don't want to disrupt their existing workflows.

That said, we do want to move towards removing the challenge period and lower registration fees, but we're also cautious in doing so to not disrupt existing systems. We understand how capable miners are of gaming systems, and we don't want to rush to any major changes. We're actively monitoring miner activity, learning from their actions, & we're working towards an automated plagiarism detection system that will flag and remove miners (moving away from a centralized system).

We are also working to make it very clear as to why a miner is performing poorly on the dashboard so its clear why a miners incentive is low. We are very active to make our systems as helpful as possible to our mining community.

Simultaneously, we're open to feedback from the community and as just occurred today, we are working towards a proposal to improve the challenge period criteria. @Thomas | Taoshi [τ, θ] is working on this right now, and we'll have an update out soon.

For clarity, there is no double dipping in penalty @Terps , we have a penalty for miners with super low MDD which should have impacted no miners (penny trades) and a penalty for high drawdown. The base augmentation is simply an expected value normalization, which puts the returns of the miners in perspective of their drawdown. As we plan to directly use the outputs of PTN to power real trading signals per @Arrash [τ, τ] 's comment, this upper augmentation penalty on higher drawdown is meant to steer miners away from the scenario where they might increase their leverage usage slightly every time they hit a new drawdown limit.

Assuming we are passing on this trading information to copy traders, a miner who breaches the 5% MDD limit will result in all positions getting closed for the copy trader, who would then take a 5% loss- as such, we want to gradually smooth the copy traders away from miners as they approach this limit. Happy to discuss a different curve to taper them off as they approach the 5% limit, but this is the purpose of the upper boundary penalty on MDD.

@antimaniac | Allan Your total score is determined based on the product of these individual categories. The numbers indicate the amount your score might drop if you are not competitive in a category. For example, let's say you are the top ranked miner for long returns and omega, but 50th percentile for short returns. Your score starts at 1, and would drop 42.5% for this ranking. If you were last place in short returns, your total score would drop by 95%. To do well, you will need to score well in all three categories (long, short, omega) such that your product sum is efficient. Max drawdown is just used for the penalty^ as Arrash mentioned

so if i were last place in short returns and 50% for long return, i get 0 score?

# Hyperparams changed on subnet 8
- `commit_reveal_weights_interval` `None` → `1000`
- `commit_reveal_weights_enabled` `None` → `False`

```
for miner, score in weighted_scores:
    if miner not in combined_scores:
        combined_scores[miner] = 1
    combined_scores[miner] *= config['weight'] * score + (1 - config['weight'])
```
You would get ((0.95 * 0.0) + (1 - 0.95)) * ((0.5 * 0.5) + (1 - 0.5)) = 0.0375.

This final score would then gets run through an exponential distribution with the total scores of the other miners: https://github.com/taoshidev/proprietary-trading-network/blob/185dc688b129e496d478c1e84982e2cb869ee552/vali_objects/scoring/scoring.py#L381
